titleStmt.title: Certaine articles, collected and taken (as it is thought) by the byshops out of a litle boke entituled an admonition to the Parliament, with an answere to the same. Containing a confirmation of the sayde booke in shorte notes
Admonition to the Parliament. Selections.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 33 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 9 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Certaine articles, collected and taken (as it is thought) by the byshops out of a litle boke entituled an admonition to the Parliament, with an answere to the same. Containing a confirmation of the sayde booke in shorte notes
Admonition to the Parliament. Selections.
titleStmt.author: Fielde, John, d. 1588, attributed name.
Cartwright, Thomas, 1535-1603, attributed name.
T. W. (Thomas Wilcox), 1549?-1608, attributed name.

publicationStmt.pubPlace: Imprinted we know where, and whan, judge you the place and you can [i.e. Hemel Hempstead?] :

notesStmt.note: Authorship uncertain. Sometimes ascribed to John Fielde and Thomas Wilcox, and also to Thomas Cartwright.
Copies differ; in this copy the title page verso has verses "To the prelacie" and B4 verso ends with 14 lines of errata for this and STC 4713.
Place and date of publication and printer's name suggested by STC.

Although this purports to answer an attack called "A viewe of the churche, that the authors of the late publyshed Admonition would haue planted", J. Whitgift on Pp2v of STC 25427 states: "no more do I [know] whether any suche collection (as you pretend) was made." --STC.
Reproduction of the original in the Yale University. Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2010-10 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2010-11 Pip WillcoxText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: ‚ùß CERTAINE Articles, collected and taken (as it is thought) by the By≈øhops out of a title boke entituled an Admonition to the Parliament / wyth an An≈øwere to the ≈øame. Containing a confirmation of the ≈øayde Booke in ≈øhorte notes.

q.p: Woe be vnto them that ≈øpeake good of euill / and euill of good / whych put darkne≈ø≈øe for light / and light for darkne≈ø≈øe / that putte bytter for ≈øweete / and ≈øweete for ≈øower.

lg.l: Thys worke is fyni≈øhed thankes be to God /
And he only wil keepe vs from the ≈øearchers rod.
And though ma≈øter Day and Toy watch & warde /
We hope the liuing God is our ≈øauegarde.
Let them ≈øeeke / loke / and we now what they can /
It is but inuentions / and pollicies of man.
But you wil maruel where it was fyni≈øhed (ended /
And you ≈øhal know (perchance) when domes day is.
Imprinted we know where / and whan /
Iudge you the place and you can.

div.p: I.T.I.S

lg.l: IF men be dumbe / ≈øure ≈øtones ≈øhall ≈øpeake /
God wyll hys truthe preuaile /
Let men re≈øi≈øt / it forceth not /
It ≈øtandes when they ≈øhall quaile.
When it of men is mo≈øt oppre≈øt /
Then God doth ≈øet in foote /
You Prelates knowe how true thys is /
Thinke then what be≈øt may boote.
You that can councell other men /
Your ≈øelues be councelled /
God will correct you knowe it well /
where it is well de≈øerued.
Yeelde rea≈øon why (none good you haue)
Gods churche / Gods orders lacke?
Not God the cau≈øe / he them requires /
Your Lord≈øhips keepe them backe.
Thinke on the time reformde to be /
Your ≈øelues which chiefly ought /
You may el≈øe kicke / you wot who ≈øayth /
Its hard auayling nought.
Repent / amende / ≈øhewe forth your loue /
You which afflicte your owne /
And we your be≈øt / whole Antichri≈øte
May quite be ouerthrowne.
By helpe of God / by helpe of Prince /
Whome God long ≈øaue and ble≈ø≈øe /
With pro≈øperous life / and earne≈øt zeale /
At la≈øt heauen to po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe.

div.head: ¬∂ A viewe of the Churche / that the Authors of the late publy≈øhed Admonition would haue plauted wythin thys realme of Englande / containing ≈øuch Po≈øitions as they hold again≈øt the ≈øtate of the ≈øayd Churche / as it is nowe.
A Reprou≈øe of thys viewe / made as it is thought / by the By≈øheps / and a Confirmation of the booke in ≈øhort notes.
div.p: WE are charged by the apo≈øtle to ≈øpeake truth / euery one to hys neighbor / which precepte I take to extende to the whole life of man / as well in matters concerning the wor≈øhyp of God and hys religion / an in them that cencerne the common lyfe „Äà‚óä„Äâ v≈øe of man. And to be faultie in it / as it is a thyng worthy reprehen≈øion in all men / ≈øo e≈øpeciallye in the mini≈øters of God / and ≈øuch as are / or ought to be by their callyng / leaders and conductors of other. I ≈øpeake not thys to carpe / or maliciou≈øly to bite any man / but to warne them brotherly of their faulte / that they may amend whych haue erred / and coÃÑmitted a ≈øcape in thys behalfe. Some when they ≈øawe the≈øe Articles ≈øayde in thys wylt: As they are in all their doings ≈øhifters / ≈øo haue they in the Collection of the≈øe Articles / ≈øhewed them ≈øelues to be no le≈ø≈øe vntrue dealers / then their cau≈øers vaine & naught: bothe for vouching thyngs out of the Booke / which are not in the boke / and al≈øo in purtyng for the mo≈øte true propo≈øitions as paradoxes.
Fol. 3. li. 1. pa. 2. Fir≈øt they holde and affirme / that wein England / are not yet come to the outward face of a church agreeable to Gods word.

In this fir≈øt Allegation there lacketh this word ≈øcar≈øe / which is in both copptes / fir≈øt and la≈øt / wherin if they had meant plainly and truely to haue dealt wyth the world / they myght haue put it downs / as it is in ye boke. Let then thynke of them as they li≈øt / but to make a lie in ye beginning / is foule & ≈øhameful.
2. lin. vlt. They will haue the mini≈øters to be called / allowed / and placed by the people.

This Article is vtterly fal≈øthed. For it is in the Admonition / the election was made by the Elders with the common con≈øent of the whole church. And ≈øo if they condempne the making of mini≈øters / what do they el≈øe / but open their mouthe again≈øt God / and again≈øt the truthe. Act. 14.23.
3 Fol. 4. li. 7. pa. 13. They wil haue none made mini≈øter / vnt ye mini≈øter of ≈øome one certain pari≈øhe.

A perillous crroure. Loke Paul ad Tit. 1.5. I thynke we haue no Apo≈øtles made now a dayes / but pa≈øtors onely: but if you think the contrary / I pray you ≈øhew me / whether ≈øuch as you make / be bounde in con≈øcience to goe unto Turcia / Barbaria and ≈øuch like places or no: or why rather they ≈øhould be bouÃÑd to England / more then to tho≈øe places: and take hed ‚Ä¢ heere o ‚Ä¢ a Popes rea≈øon.
4 lin. 9. They holde that a by≈øhop at no hand / hath authoritie to ordaine mini≈øters.

No / not alone / but as part of the con≈øi≈øtorie / and elder≈øhip and member of the church / as Act. 1. And a by≈øhop as ours are / that is Romi≈øh by≈øhops / creatures of the Canon law by no meanes.
5. lin. 17. They ≈øay for a by≈øhop to ≈øay to the mini≈øter / Receiue the holy gho≈øte / is bla≈øphemous and ridiculous.
Is this put downe as an error? in dede it is erroneous if the holy gho≈øt proceede from them: but ye let them con≈øider of Caluu:. Io. 20.22.
6 lin. 28. They will haue the mini≈øters at their owne plea≈øure to preach wythout lycence.

Thys is al≈øo fal≈øifyed / the boke hath it / if any be ≈øo wel di≈øpo≈øed to preach in their owne charges / they may not wythout my Lordes licence. A ≈øhamefull corruption. Any rea≈øonable man would haue known by the ≈øecond Article / that no man can be a preacher at hys owne plea≈øure / but by the admi≈ø≈øion of the coÃÑ gregation / but as afore / ≈øo ≈øay we againe. A Romi≈øh
bi≈øhop hath nought to do / to geue licence / and hys is as good to preache by / as the Popes calfe was that Felton ≈øet vp.

7 lin. 13. Fol. 17. li. 6. pa. 1. They will haue the mini≈øters di≈øcerned from others by no kind of apparell / and the apparell appoynted / they terme antichri≈øtian / & the apparell appoynted by ye Prince / di≈øobedyence again≈øt the Prince.

Thys al≈øo is fal≈øifyed / they ≈øpeake of the ≈øimple kinde of ≈øetting for the the ≈øacraments of Chri≈øte / and afterward in the purer churches / & compare it wyth the pelfe of beaurifying it (as they woulde haue it ≈øeeme) only found out and appoynted by popes from Paganes: The wordes are the≈øe / they mini≈øtred the ≈øacramentes plainly / we pompou≈øly / wyth ≈øynging / piping / ≈øurple≈ø≈øe / and coape wearing / ≈øo I finde it in Fol. 4. pa. 2. lin. 15. Whether the appared be Antichri≈øtian or no / it is no time here to debate / but lette them ≈øhew from whence they had it? and le ‚Ä¢ theÃÑ not be a≈øhamed to profe≈ø≈øe hys name / who≈øe cogni≈øance they weare. Eyther let them ≈øpeake as they are apparelled / or lette them apparell them≈øelues as they ≈øpeake. But I cry them mercy / they do ≈øo now / and neuer ≈øo plainly / I am ≈øure they haue put forth here articles / whych they ≈øhall neuer be able to ≈øhewe any ground for / vnle≈ø≈øe they take it from the Pope. And thys I ≈øay to al good Chri≈øtians / let them take hede that they haue not the ≈øupremacie of the Pope maintayned heere / while≈øt a fewe white coates ≈øtande for hundred poundes / I ≈øay not thou≈øandes. For thys viewe which they put forthe / drawing ≈øo many articles out of that ≈ømall boke / ab≈øurde as they ≈øeeme to put them forthe / containeth in it / ≈øo many fal≈øe articles cleane agayn≈øt the truthe and the booke / as are by them put downe.

8 Fo. 4. li. 1. pa. 2. They will haue all Archby≈øhops / bi≈øhops / archdeacons / chaunceilors / and all other eccle≈øia≈øticall officers together with their titles / iuri≈ødictions / courtes / and lyuings cleane taken
away / and wyth ≈øpeede remoned.

Fal≈øifyed in part. They haue ≈ølily left out that / that they could nor / but be a≈øhamed of / if they had any ≈øhame / as Lords grace / Iu≈øtice of ‚Ä¢ eace & Quorum / whych haue no ground nor warrant in Gods boke. But I doubt not when they come to „Äà‚óä„Äâ the boke / or put ‚Ä¢ owne the confirmation of their „Äà‚óä„Äâ to continue the≈øe ab≈øura ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ c ‚Ä¢ we ≈øhall ≈øee good
„Äà‚óä„Äâ .

„Äà‚óä„Äâ for
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈øe / as though it were a ‚Ä¢ ab≈øu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e to ≈øay they ought to be taken away / why not a Card ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll at ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ er ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ burye / as well as an ab ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ onage

„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ / we will yeede thys is ab≈øurde.

11 Fol.
‚Ä¢ . li. 15.16.21.17. They will haue no hon ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es red in the Churche / no ‚Ä¢ articles / nor in
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ et: o ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øet out nor v≈øed /
‚Ä¢ or in no wi≈øe Sacraments muu≈øtred in any hou≈øe / nor in no wy≈øe the word red / but preached only.

A ha ‚Ä¢ ous error.
‚Ä¢ te predicate. Math. 28. goe and preach. Et quo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ que con ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s ali ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ alium
expeca ‚Ä¢ te. 1. Cor. 11. So oft as ye come together / tarye one for another. Priuate hou≈øes are not m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e for ≈øacramentes to be mini≈øtred in / when there is an open coÃÑgre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tion. They haue no cau≈øe to think of our mo≈øt gracious Queene ≈øo wickedly / as yt they ≈øhuld be driuen to maintaine that ab≈øurb and di≈øorderous order. Thankes be to God / all chu ‚Ä¢ ch dores are open / and god long pre≈øerue her maie≈øtie among vs / by who≈øe intants they are open. Why ≈øhuld that be tollerated / which is a coÃÑfirming of their popi≈øh hoa≈øling / and the priuate midwiues bapti≈øing.
12 They will not haue the Epi≈øtle and Go≈øpell red / and what≈øoeuer is ≈øayde before / they vtterly mi≈ølike / and call it a Popes entraunce.
Where el≈øe had yet it? and ≈øuch patching was neuer taken but fro Rome / ≈øhew authoritie if they caÃÑ.
13 pa. 2. li. 17.10. They cannot abide to haue the Crede red at the Communion.
No / not as a peece of your ma≈ø≈øe / yet we v≈øe it in all our churches in euery ≈øermon / it is not done for ye contempt of the Crede I would ye knew it.
14 Pa. 1. lin. 20. They wil haue the Communion receiued at the table ≈øitting / without further reuerence / kneeling they ≈øay / is vtterly vnlawful.
Chri≈øt v≈øed it ≈øytting / Antychri≈øt kneling / whether is better to haue Moi≈øes or a Calfe?
15 lin. 14. They mi≈ølyke of the≈øe woordes / the bodye of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øte. &c.
Why coÃÑtent you not your ≈øelues with Chri≈øtes words and the Apo≈øtles? Eyther foly≈øh Paule and wy≈øe you / or foly≈øh you and wy≈øe the Apo≈øtles.
16 lin. 15. They mi≈ølyke of Gloria in excel≈øis.
Not euery thing that is good / is to be patched into the Communion / becau≈øe that chri≈øtians ought not to make quidlibet ex quolibet of a rede a rammes horne.
17 lin. 12. They will haue no other words / nor circum≈øtance made / then Chri≈øte v≈øed.

17 lin. 12. Fal≈øifyed / the words are / we ≈øynfully
mixed wyth mannes inuentions. Speake truthe if thou can / and ≈øhame the deuill.
18 Fol. 6. pa. 1. lin. 12. They will haue no Papi≈øte / neyther wyth hys will / nor con≈øtrayned to receyue the Communion.

Ah Paule what mente≈øt thou. Probet ≈øeip≈øum homo. 1. Cor. 11. Let a man examine hym≈øelfe. I tell you / the ≈øacramentes are too muche abu≈øed by men wyllingly. Adde not more ≈øynnes to cau≈øe the Lords wrathe to be more hotte again≈øt vs.
19 line. 16. They will haue no Godfathers nor Godmothers.
Vtterly fal≈øifyed.
20 Fol. 6. lin. 6. pag. 1. They wyll haue all mini≈øters equall.
Chri≈øte in deede erred in thys / therefore we recant / inter vos autem non ≈øic. It ≈øhall not be ≈øo among you. Luke. 22.
21 lin. 10. They mi≈ølike all collectors for ye pore.
And would haue Deacons placed / who≈øe offyce it is. Act. 6. Rom. 12.

22 Fol. 8. in fine. They ≈øay that there may be yet a more perfect forme & order of a church drawne / and that thys is but an entrauÃÑce to a further matter / promi≈øing that they wil yet go further therin.

Fal≈øifyed. Sed audin? verbum vnum caue de pleniore Chri≈øto / ne ad morbum hoc etiam. Yet ≈øee howe the≈øe men are troubled / euen as legio was to heare of Chri≈øtes coÃÑming. It greueth them to heare that Chri≈øt ≈øhuld be ful among≈øt vs / and not by patches and peeces.
Out of the ≈øeconde treati≈øe called a viewe of popi≈øhe abu≈øes remayning.
Note three Articles omitted.

And why the≈øe more then the re≈øt? if it be for yt you are a≈øhamed of your vngodly dealyng / with your fellow brethren / whome you and the re≈øt of the hygh Commi≈ø≈øioners at Lambeth put from their liuings and mini≈øterie for refu≈øyng to ≈øub≈øcribe to your traditions
it is well: if it be for that you ≈øee them ≈øo ≈øuffyciently confuted / as you haue nothing to reply / you are to be borne wythall in hope of amendement.
1 Fol. 10. pag. 1. lin. 33. Reading of ≈øeruice or homelies in the Churche they ≈øay / is as euill as playing on a ≈øtage / and wor≈øe too.

Fal≈øifyed / and yet marke I pray you their rea≈øon and compari≈øon / not for the thing it ≈øelfe / but for the per≈øons them ≈øelues. For the players can ≈øaye their partes without booke / the≈øe for the mo≈øte parte can but read theirs / and that ≈øcar≈øe too.

2 Fol. 12. pa. 2. lin. 10. Touching mariage / they A mi≈ølike the wedding ring / they are angrye wyth B taking of it vp / and laying of it downe. They will not haue ≈øhe Trinitie named therein. They ≈øay we make the man to make an idol of his wife / becau≈øe he ≈øayth / wyth this ring I the wed / with my body I thee wor≈øhyp.
A In deede they are pretie iugling ca≈øtes / taken out of the Popes Ma≈ø≈øe booke / as the mo≈øte parte of all their tra≈øhe. Rub. manu trahendo. Tit. Benedictio ≈øpon≈øi & ≈øpon≈øe.

B It is plaine abu≈øing of the name of God borowed from thence too. You myght haue foun ‚Ä¢ better rea≈øon to haue condempned thys for a ≈øuper≈øtitious thyng / then a graye ammi≈ø≈øe / for you haue the≈øe wycked words put to it. Et proficiat illi ad eternam ≈øalutem. And that it may profite hym to eternall ≈øaluation. Ca. Cretor. Thys were as good an occa≈øion to ca≈øt it awaye / as Ezechias had to breake the ≈øerpent / and for your pretie v≈øing of it / let the Reader loke vpon the Rub. Tune a≈øpergatur.
3 lin. 3. Confirmation they mi≈ø≈øelike / and call it ≈øuper≈øtitious / popi≈øhe / and peeui≈øhe.

Farre ouer ≈øeene in ≈øo doing. It was a Sacrament / and may be ≈øtill if it plea≈øe you. For you
‚Ä¢ ertefie the childe of Gods grace.
A 4 Fol. 13. pa. 1. lin. 1. Touching buriall of the dead / they will haue no pre≈øcript ≈øeruice for it.
